question_text: The pie chart below has the breakup of the number of students from different departments in an engineering college for the year 2012. The proportion of male to female students in each department is 5:4. There are 40 males in Electrical Engineering. What is the difference between the numbers of female students in the Civil department and the female students in the Mechanical department?

question_text: Let f(x) = x-(1/3) and A denote the area of the region bounded by f(x) and the X-axis, when x varies from -1 to 1. Which of the following statements is/are TRUE?
options: II) f is not bounded in [-1, 1]
III) A is nonzero and finite
subject: Engineering Mathematics

question_text: Suppose L = {p,q,r,s, t}, is a lattice represented by the following Hasse diagram: For any x, y ∈ L, not necessarily distinct, x V y and x A y are join and meet of x, y, respectively. Let L³ = {(x, y, z): x, y, z E L}, be the set of all ordered triplets of the elements of L. Let p, be the probability that an element (x, y, z) ∈ L³ chosen equiprobably satisfies x V (y ∧ z) = (x V y) ∧ (x V z). Then
subject: Engineering Mathematics
diagram_mermaid_code:
graph TD
    subgraph Hasse Diagram
        t --> q
        t --> s
        q --> p
        s --> p
    end

question_text:
A variable x is said to be live at a statement Sᵢ in a program if the following three conditions hold simultaneously:
i. There exists a statement Sⱼ that uses x
ii. There is a path from Sᵢ to Sⱼ in the flow graph corresponding to the program
iii. The path has no intervening assignment to x including at Sᵢ and Sⱼ

The variables which are live both at the statement in basic block 2 and at the statement in basic block 3 of the above control flow graph are
subject: Compiler Design

question_text: Consider the DFAs M and N given above. The number of states in a minimal DFA that accepts the language L(M) ∩ L(N) is
subject: Theory of Computation

    subgraph DFA M
        direction LR
        M_S1(( ))
        M_S2(( ))
        M_S1 -- b --> M_S1
        M_S1 -- a --> M_S2
        M_S2 -- a --> M_S2
        M_S2 -- b --> M_S1
    end
    subgraph DFA N
        direction LR
        N_S1(( ))
        N_S2(( ))
        N_S1 -- a --> N_S1
        N_S1 -- b --> N_S2
        N_S2 -- b --> N_S2
        N_S2 -- a --> N_S1
    end
